; <L>50294<pc>282,3<k1>kim<k2>kim<h>b<e>2
174789 old <s>kim</s> <hom>b</hom> ¦ is much used as a particle of interrogation like the <ab>Lat.</ab> <etym>num</etym>, <etym>an</etym>, sometimes translatable by ‘whether?’ but oftener serving only like a note of interrogation to mark a question (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kiM vyADA vane 'smin saMcaranti</s>, ‘do hunters roam about in this wood?’ In an interrogation the verb, if uncompounded with a preposition, generally retains its accent after <s>kim</s>, <ls>Pāṇ. 8-1, 44</ls>). To this sense may be referred the <s>kim</s> expressing inferiority, deficiency, &c. at the beginning of compounds (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kiM-rAjan</s>, what sort of king? <ab>i.e.</ab> a bad king, <ls>Pāṇ. 2-1, 64</ls>; <ls n="Pāṇ.">5-4, 70</ls>)
;
174789 new <s>kim</s> <hom>b</hom> ¦ is much used as a particle of interrogation like the <ab>Lat.</ab> <etym>num</etym>, <etym>an</etym>, sometimes translatable by ‘whether?’ but oftener serving only like a note of interrogation to mark a question (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kiM vyADA vane 'smin saMcaranti</s>, ‘do hunters roam about in this wood?’ In an interrogation the verb, if uncompounded with a preposition, generally retains its accent after <s>kim</s>, <ls>Pāṇ. viii, 1, 44</ls>). To this sense may be referred the <s>kim</s> expressing inferiority, deficiency, &c. at the beginning of compounds (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kiM-rAjan</s>, what sort of king? <ab>i.e.</ab> a bad king, <ls>Pāṇ. ii, 1, 64</ls>; <ls n="Pāṇ.">v, 4, 70</ls>)
; -------------------------
